Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, (b) BJH pore diameter distribution curves for two catalysts. Table 2 Catalysts Mn4+/Mn (%) Mn3+/Mn (%) Mn2+/Mn (%) OS/(OS+OL) (%) Mn-AC 20.9 50.6 28.5 40.1 Mn-AH 19.1 30.1 50.7 30.1 Structure-activity strategy comparison of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst for low-temperature NO abatement Zhichao Chen Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Shan Ren Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition ⁎ Mingming Wang Investigation Validation Data curation Lin Chen Resources Conceptualization Xiaodi Li Methodology Jiangling Li Data curation Jian Yang Investigation Qingcai Liu Investigation College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, PR China College of Materials Science and Engineering Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 PR China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Herein, the structure-activity strategy comparison of two different precipitants on MnO x catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR was investigated in detail. XRD results confirmed that ammonium carbonate (denoted as AC) could transfer manganese precursor from MnCO3 to Mn2O3 phase with temperature from 80 to 450 °C, while ammonium hydroxide (denoted as AH) facilitated the phase transition of MnO x from Mn3O4 to the final Mn5O8 phase. Further morphology defined that Mn-AC catalyst possessed a peculiar spherical feature while Mn-AH catalyst presented an accumulation of abundant nano-particles. The activity results suggested that Mn-AC catalyst possessed higher activity compared with Mn-AH catalyst at lower temperature, with over 60% conversion achieved from 100 to 225 °C and the maximum NO conversion reached circa (denoted as ca.) 85% at 175 °C. In addition, Mn-AC catalyst possessed stronger surface acidity and redox properties than Mn-AH catalyst, which served as an important motivation for the difference in activity. More manganese ions with higher valence and surface oxygen favored the superior redox circle of Mn-AC catalyst. Transient reaction revealed that the catalysts followed both Eley–Rideal (E-R) and Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) pathways while the L-H pathway was harder to occur than the former due to the intense NO x transformation over catalysts. On account of these analyses, the possible structure-activity strategy comparison model of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst was proposed. Graphical abstract The anions of precipitant played a leading role in the formation of the catalytic phase and surface morphology, in which AC induced active Mn precursor to transfer from MnCO3 to spherical Mn2O3 while AH developed the initial Mn3O4 to final Mn5O8 phase. The transition behavior of active precursors under different precipitants was the root cause of the internal motivation of catalytic properties. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Structure-activity strategy (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants Pure MnO x Low-temperature NO abatement Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) from stationary and mobile sources caused serious environmental issues such as haze, acid rain, photochemical smog, etc [1,2]. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x using ammonia (NH3-SCR) was deemed as one of the most promising approaches to control nitrogen oxide emission in the past decades [3,4]. V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, as the most widely-applied product, suggested satisfactory denitrification efficiency and good stability at 300-400 °C [5–7]. Nevertheless, vanadium toxicity and higher activation temperature window posed a barrier for it to meet the application in low-temperature non-electric industries whose flue gas temperature was usually below 250 °C [8,9]. Thus, it was highly incentive to develop the novel non-vanadium catalysts with excellent efficiency and environmental friendliness for the low-temperature NH3-SCR (LTNS) system. In recent years, manganese oxides aroused much attention because of their inherently LT superior redox capacity from the migration of electrons in the d shell [2,6,10–12]. To achieve effective utilization of manganese compositions on LTNS catalysts, researchers developed lots of efforts in controlling the phase transition of active Mn precursors during the synthesis process. Summarizing previous literatures, in general, the active component oxides on catalysts could be fabricated via two main evolution pathways: (I) decomposing directly of active Mn-bearing precursor via typical impregnation or solid grinding methods [13,14]; (II) achieving a continuous evolution from one status to the other via precipitation, citric acid or hydrothermal methods [15–17]. Among them, the precipitation method accounted for a large proportion in the formation of pure MnO x catalysts due to its desirable operability [18,19]. It should be mentioned that precipitants served a critical role in modulating the phase transition behaviors of active constituents during the precipitation system [20]. For instance, the MnSO4 precursor could be transformed into the ultimate Mn3O4 spinel under sodium hydroxide while to final K-α-MnO2 nanorod by changing the precipitant to potassium permanganate [21,22]. Such results confirmed that precipitant could induce the structure and oxidation state of MnO x to a great extent. However, up to now, there was still seldom work focused on the structure-activity correlation of precipitants on pure MnO x catalyst for LTNS, much less to comparatively analyze their internal motivations either. On this basis, the investigation of the structure-activity strategy of different precipitants on the pure MnO x catalysts during the precipitation process was imperative and valuable for the effective design of Mn-based catalysts. In this research, two typical precipitants (ammonium carbonate and ammonium hydroxide) were selected to reveal the structure-activity relation of precipitants on pure manganese oxides in detail. Meanwhile, the physicochemical property of catalyst was clarified in depth using several techniques as well. Finally, the possible structure-activity model of two precipitants on the MnO x catalyst was proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The different precipitants of bearing-carbonate or -hydroxyl induced pure manganese oxide catalysts were synthesized via a PEG-assisted co-precipitation method. The sample was denoted as Mn-X catalyst, where X stood for the used precipitants. The synthesis processes and characterization details were described in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.2 Catalysts activity test The NO removal efficiency of samples was evaluated at the fixed-bed reaction system, and the space velocity was set as 100,000 h−1. Reactive atmosphere involved 500 ppm [NH3] and [NO], 5 vol% [O2], 5 vol% [H2O] (when used), 100 ppm [SO2] (when used) and balance gas [N2]. Outlet gas composition was determined on Thermo Fisher Scientific, Antaris IGS. The relevant performance indexes were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) NO conversion ( % ) = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = [ N O x ] i n − [ N O x ] o u t + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O x ] i n − [ N O x ] o u t + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t × 100 The subscripts in and out were the gas concentration of inlet and outlet for reaction system. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Active phase transition mechanism To investigate the realistic phase evolution approaches of catalysts with different anionic precipitants, XRD analysis was used and corresponding patterns were illustrated in Fig. 1 . From Fig. 1(a), carbonate-bearing precipitant induced the active Mn precursor to form MnCO3 species (PDF 44–1472) firstly, and then decomposing into the final Mn2O3 phase (PDF 41–1442) at 450 °C. For comparison, Mn3O4 phase (PDF 80–0382) was fabricated in the initial drying stage by ammonium hydroxide, then it was further transferred towards Mn5O8 (PDF 72–1427) with thermal treatment. After eliminating the effect of common cations, such phenomenon confirmed the anions of precipitant played a critical role in phase structure transition of Mn-bearing precursor. On this basis, the formation mechanism of manganese oxides under different precipitants during the heating process could be summarized in Eqs. (3) and (4) in sequence [23,24]. (3) Mn − AC : 2 MnC O 3 + 1 / 2 O 2 → M n 2 O 3 + 2 C O 2 (4) Mn − AH : M n 3 O 4 + 2 / 5 O 2 → 3 / 5 M n 5 O 8 From previous reports, it should be noted that Mn2O3 oxides had been considered to be more active for reactants, which favored the SCR reaction [6,25]. Similarly, Mn5O8 oxides as a combination of Mn2+ and Mn4+ had also been applied extensively in high-voltage aqueous sodium-ion storage due to its excellent redox and dual-electron transfer channel [26]. Though, the real NH3-SCR adaptability of two Mn oxides had not been compared in previous work. Thus, the relevant structure-activity correlation could be investigated through the following characterizations. 3.2 Microscopic morphology features Fig. 2 further explored the microscopic surface structure of catalysts via the SEM and TEM analysis. From Fig. 2(a), a peculiar spherical feature with the relatively huge size was observed on the AC-treated Mn2O3 catalyst, in accord with the findings from Yang et al. [24]. However, AH-treated MnO x catalyst exhibited more like an accumulation of nano-particles which originated from the successful assembly of layered-Mn5O8 nanocrystals from Fig. 2(c) [23]. Considering the lattice fringes of Mn5O8 from Fig. 2(d), the exposed crystal plane could be assigned to the abundant (111) facets, which was consistent with the main phase peaks of Fig. 1(d) patterns. Considering the phase transition and surface structure features of catalysts (Figs. 1 and 2), the transition process of catalysts under different precipitants was proposed in Scheme 1 . 3.3 Surface pore structure The porosity characteristics for two catalysts were revealed by N2-physisorption experiment, and the curves were shown in Fig. 3 . Evidently, a type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves along with a concomitant H2-type hysteresis loops existed on all catalysts, which reflected the capillary condensation characteristic of mesoporous catalysts [2,5]. Interestingly, both the inflection position of P/P0 values and volume of adsorbed nitrogen over Mn-AC catalyst expressed the valid offset compared with that over Mn-AH catalyst, meaning more abundant pore channels structure on the former [27]. Based on this, AC-treated pure Mn oxides embraced a relatively higher BET area for 73 m2/g and pore volume for 0.32 cm3/g than that of Mn-AH catalyst at only 13 m2/g and 0.06 cm3/g (Table 1 ). It might be associated with the pore optimization due to the release of CO2 gas molecules during MnCO3 heating process. Previous literatures pointed out that favorable surface area and pore volume offered more reaction channels and surface active sites, which were conductive to reactants’ adsorption during the SCR reaction [28]. 3.4 Catalytic performance The catalytic activity of catalysts as the function of reaction temperature was given in Fig. 4(a). It was apparent that the catalytic property of pure Mn oxides induced by different anions was sensitive to reaction temperature especially for a higher space velocity of 100,000 h−1. Mn-AC catalyst exhibited a higher NO removal efficiency than Mn-AH at the lower temperature, with over 60% conversion achieved from 100 to 225 °C and the maximum conversion reached circa (denoted as ca.) 85% at 175 °C. In contrast, Mn-AH catalyst embraced the relatively lower catalytic activity and the maximum conversion was only ca. 75 % below 250 °C. The circulation activity test of Fig. S1 further verified the stability of two catalysts during the SCR process. In addition, both catalysts displayed a poor N2 selectivity with temperature, which was the usual drawback of pure Mn oxides [18,19]. Such results confirmed that the MnO x catalysts with peculiar phase and structure did present a different catalytic activity, in which the AC had a remarkable advantage in promoting the catalytic activity of MnO x catalysts than AH precipitant. In practical applications, water vapor and SO2 always existed in the exhaust gases even through the desulphurization unit, which caused severe inactivation of catalysts [5]. Thus, the H2O and SO2 tolerance test was carried out and the results were shown in Fig. 4(b). After introducing the water vapor and SO2, the NO conversion of both catalysts exhibited a rapid decrease in the initial 150 min, and the two MnO x catalysts were almost completely inactivated with extending time. The reason might originate from the sulfation of active Mn, resulting in the damage of active sites on catalysts [2,10]. When SO2 and H2O were removed, the activity remained no change for two catalysts, reflecting an irreversible deactivation of SO2 on pure MnO x catalysts. In addition, some other researchers also confirmed the poor SO2 and H2O tolerance of MnO x catalysts [18,21,29]. 3.5 Surface chemical states XPS technique was also used to study the chemical state of active elements over Mn-AC and Mn-AH catalysts, and the spectra were revealed in Fig. 5 . From Fig. 5(a), Mn 2p 3/2 orbit could be fitted well into four representative characteristic peaks, corresponding to Mn2+ (640.9 eV), Mn3+ (642.2 eV), Mn4+ (644.5 eV), and satellite peak of Mn species (646.5 eV), respectively [4,29–31]. The calculated surface atomic ratios were listed in Table 2 . For Mn-AC catalyst, the Mn3+ accounted for a significant proportion in all Mn-bearing ions, in accordance with the existing Mn2O3 phase (Fig. 1(c)). In terms of Mn-AH catalyst, Mn5O8 phase expressed more Mn2+ as a combination of Mn2+ and Mn4+ as reported in [26]. Further comparing to two catalysts, the Mn4+ concentration exhibited barely difference while the Mn3+ ratio of Mn-AC catalyst was ca. 20% higher than that of Mn-AH catalyst. The manganese metal ions with higher oxidation status were deemed to be more active for the redox circle reaction during the SCR process [5,6]. Fig. 5(b) displayed the O 1s spectra of the two catalysts, and the characteristic peaks at ca. 529.9 and 531.5 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen (O2−, labeled as OL) and surface labile oxygen (O2 2− or O−, labeled as OS) [32,33]. Previous literatures pointed out that OS was considered to be more active than OL species because of its higher mobility [5,34]. From Fig. 5(b), it was seen that Mn-AC catalyst possessed a higher OS ratio of 40.1% than that of Mn-AH catalyst at 30.1%. The reason might be related to the intense redox circle induced by the more abundant Mn3+ over the Mn-AC catalyst. The abundant manganese ions with higher valence and surface oxygen favored the redox properties of catalysts, which significantly contributed to the SCR reaction [5,6]. It might be one of the factors for activity difference between the two catalysts. 3.6 Surface acidity and redox property It was reported that surface acidities and redox properties of catalysts served as crucial roles in reactants adsorption and intermediates transformation [5,35,36]. Thus, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR analyses were applied to investigate the mentioned surface chemical properties, and the results were illustrated in Fig. 6(a) and (b). From Fig. 6(a), both catalysts exhibited two distinguishable peaks from 50 to 650 °C, in which peaks at ca. 103 °C were the NH3 adsorbed on the weak acid sites, while the higher temperature (596 and 450 °C) belonged to the chemical NH3 adsorption on strong acid sites [5]. Clearly, Mn-AC catalyst possessed a higher temperature and more amounts of NH3 desorption than that of Mn-AH catalyst, confirming the stronger surface acidity of the former in whichever strength or quantity, which favored the adsorption and activation of ammonia species during the NH3-SCR reaction [29,32]. Fig. 6(b) revealed the reduction behaviors of active elements on catalysts using H2-TPR analysis. Regarding Mn-AC catalyst, peaks at ca. 320, 367 and 484 °C could belong to the reductions of active oxygen, Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and Mn3O4 to MnO in sequence [5,6]. In terms of Mn-AH catalyst, peaks at ca. 367 and 542 °C were ascribed to the reduction process of Mn5O8 → Mn3O4 → MnO [23]. Noticeably, more O species, including lattice nonstoichiometric oxygen and surface oxygen, were also involved in the transition reaction of Mn-AC catalyst, which upgraded the additional redox capacity of catalyst in addition to metal ions at low temperature [5,37]. Moreover, the reduction temperature of Mn3O4 to MnO also exhibited a considerable transition tendency towards lower temperature from Mn-AH to Mn-AC catalyst. On this basis, it could be concluded that AC-treated MnO x catalyst possessed stronger redox properties, especially for the low-temperature region, in favor of the LTNS reaction. 3.7 Surface derivatives evolution behaviors The adsorption behavior of reactants during SCR process was analyzed firstly using in situ DRIFTS at 175 °C, the spectra were presented in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7(a), after adding NH3, bands at 1185 and 1610 cm−1 both appeared on Mn-AC catalyst, assigning to the coordinated NH3 which was bound to the Lewis acid sites [5,38,39]. With further extending adsorption time, the adsorbed ammonia substances were dehydrogenated steadily into the new active amide/imide (-NH2/-NH) (at 1512 cm−1) and oxidation/deformation species (1270 cm-1) [34]. Such transformation reflected the excellent NH3 activation capacity on Mn-AC catalyst. Similar band transition characteristics also existed on the Mn-AH catalyst except for a new negative band at 1335 cm−1 due to the consumed NH3 by hydroxyl group (Fig. 7(b)) [40]. Nevertheless, the band intensity for Mn-AC catalyst was stronger than Mn-AH catalyst in whichever NH3 adsorption or transformation, which confirmed the enhanced NH3 adsorption and activation ability of Mn-AC catalyst, in line with Fig. 6(a). Fig. 7(c) and (d) illustrated the spectra of NO and O2 co-adsorption on Mn-AC and Mn-AH catalysts in sequence. Form Fig. 7(c), several bands corresponding to the adsorbed NO2 (1627 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1555 and 1215 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1254 cm−1) were observed on Mn-AC catalyst after adsorbing NO+O2 [4,5]. Interestingly, these nitrate substances remained strengthening in an initial 4 min while turned to decline in the next 46 min, demonstrating a self-decomposition and transformation phenomenon of NO x species at high temperature [5]. Regarding Mn-AH catalyst, the nitrates were coincident with that of Mn-AC catalyst and a new band near 1350 cm−1 linked to an interaction of the adsorbed NO and superoxide radicals (O2 −) also was detected [40]. Moreover, different from the former, Mn-AH seemed to possess a stronger nitrates generation in the initial stage especially for the adsorbed NO2 species, which might contribute to the “Fast SCR” reaction. However, associating with real activity of catalysts, the nitrates of Mn-AH catalyst might not fully participate in the reaction. The depth mechanism could be explored through the following transient reactions. The derivatives transition mechanism of catalysts was further clarified through the transient reactions between adsorbed reactants at 175 °C, the spectra were displayed in Fig. 8 . From Fig. 8(a), the NH3 adsorption behavior over Mn-AC catalyst was similar to that of shown in Fig. 7(a). After adding NO and O2, the adsorbed NH3 (1184 cm−1) was reacted immediately and consumed completely in 5 min. Subsequently, the nitrates such as adsorbed NO2 (1627 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1555 and 1215 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1254 cm−1) were formed on catalyst and maintained growing with NO+O2 adsorption. Actually, the transformation behavior of NO x species still occurred on Mn-AC catalyst under preadsorbed NH3 condition. For the Mn-AH catalyst, there were still weak bands related to the adsorbed ammonia derivatives appeared after NH3 adsorption just like Fig. 7(b). Further injecting NO+O2, the adsorbed ammonia species reacted with NO+O2, while the reaction rate between reactants exhibited a distinct difference and it took over 10 min to finish the consumption of adsorbed ammonia. On this basis, it could preliminarily deduce that both Mn-AC and Mn-AH catalysts obeyed the Eley–Rideal (E-R) mechanism of adsorbed NH3 reacted with NO during the SCR reaction, and the former conducted a higher reaction level than the latter. Actually, although Mn-AH possessed the relatively excellent NO2 adsorption capability as mentioned before, the weak NH3 adsorption still confined the reaction efficiency between reactants, leading to its poor activity in Fig. 4. Fig. 8(c) and (d) showed the spectra of preadsorbed NO and O2, followed by the NH3 adsorption on the catalysts. It should be mentioned that NH3 was introduced into reaction system only after NO+O2 adsorption for 50 min, thus the original band intensity of NO x species over all catalysts expressed an evident weakness due to its transformation behavior as indicated in Fig. 7(c) and (d). With adding NH3, the intensity of NO x species exhibited a sluggish change until the new ammonia bands covered its position. Therefore, the reaction between adsorbed NO x and NH3 species could also exist on two catalysts although it seemed to be so hard to occur because of the intense NO x evolution behaviors of pure MnO x . In fact, many reports also had confirmed that pure MnO x was difficult to proceed with a reaction between adsorbed NO x species and NH3 compared with gaseous NO and adsorbed NH3 [2,5,19]. Combining the above results, we could define that both E-R and L-H pathways occurred on these catalysts, while the E-R pathway played a dominant role in the NH3-SCR process. 3.8 Reaction mechanism over catalysts Herein, the structure-activity strategy comparison of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst for low-temperature NO x abatement was investigated. According to the phase transition behaviors in Fig. 1, the precursor of active manganese could transfer from MnCO3 to the ultimate Mn2O3 phase with rising temperature under carbonate-bearing precipitant. However, the hydroxyl-bearing precipitant induced the phase transition of MnO x from Mn3O4 to the final Mn5O8 phase. It confirmed the anions of precipitants played a decisive role in the formation of active Mn phase during the synthesis process. And Mn-AC catalyst had a peculiar spherical feature while Mn-AH catalyst presented an accumulation of abundant nano-particles. On account of the phase and structure analysis, the possible synthesis process was shown in Scheme 1. In response to the above features, the pore structure of catalysts exhibited an obvious difference in which Mn-AC possessed a higher surface area and pore volume than that Mn-AH catalyst, which was beneficial for the adsorption of reactants [28,37]. Actually, the inherent textural nature of catalyst composition served as the real motivation for the physicochemical properties. Thus, Mn-AC possessed the higher catalytic activity compared with Mn-AH catalyst especially for the low-temperature region. XPS technique was applied to study the chemical state of active species further. More manganese ions with higher valence and surface oxygen favored the superior redox properties of Mn-AC catalyst, which significantly contributed to the SCR reaction. Previous literatures reported that NH3 adsorption process was considered as the crucial step in the NH3-SCR reaction and surface acidities played an important role for its adsorption [16,41]. The results defined that Mn-AC possessed the stronger surface acidity in whichever strength or quantity than Mn-AH catalyst, it might be one of the reasons why the activity exhibited a distinct difference. H2-TPR analysis supported the previous deduction in XPS, and more available O species, involved in the reduction reaction of Mn-AC catalyst, contributed to stronger redox properties at low temperature. The transient reaction elaborated the evolution behavior of active intermediates during the SCR process. From results, both catalysts followed the E-R and L-H pathways while the L-H pathway was harder to occur than the former due to the intense NO x transformation over catalysts. For a typical E-R mechanism, the reaction could be listed as Eqs. (5)–(10): (5) N H 3 ( g ) + * → L N H 3 ( ads ) − * (6) O 2 ( g ) + * → M 2 O ( ads ) − * (7) N H 3 ( ads ) − * + O ( ads ) − * → M * − N H 2 ( ads ) + * − O H ( ads ) (8) * − N H 2 ( ads ) + O ( ads ) − * → M * − N H ( ads ) + * − O H ( ads ) (9) N O ( g ) + − N H 2 ( ads ) → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O (10) N O ( g ) + − N H ( ads ) → N 2 O ( g ) + H ( ads ) + Firstly, the gaseous NH3 was adsorbed on catalysts as a coordinated NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites. It should be noted that Mn-AC possessed the stronger L-NH3 than Mn-AH catalyst and no obvious band of ionic NH4 + linked to Brønsted acid was observed on all catalysts. After that, the ammonia species was dehydrogenated into intermediates amides/imides steadily with the assistance of oxygen species Eqs. (7) and ((8)). With introducing NO+O2, the gaseous NO could react with existing ammonia species to yield N2 and byproduct N2O through Eqs. (9) and 10 ). For the L-H mechanism, the NO+O2 could be adsorbed on catalysts and transferred toward stable nitrates via Eqs. (11)–(13 ). Further adding NH3, the gaseous NH3 transferred into adsorbed ammonia species and reacted with nitrates to form NH4NO3 and NH4NO2, then decomposed into N2 and N2O (Eqs. (18) and ((19)). (11) N O ( g ) + * → N O ( ads ) − * (12) * − N O ( ads ) + O ( ads ) − * → M N O 2 ( ads ) / * − N O 2 ( ads ) (13) * − N O 2 ( ads ) + O ( ads ) − * → M * − N O 3 ( ads ) (18) * − N O 2 ( ads ) + NH 4 ( ads ) + − * → M N H 4 N O 2 ( ads ) → N 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O (19) * − N O 3 ( ads ) + NH 4 ( ads ) + − * → M N H 4 N O 3 ( ads ) → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O Actually, due to the strong NO x transformation, L-H pathway was hard to occur on two catalysts. Thus, both two catalysts mainly followed the E-R mechanism. Based on these analyses, the possible mechanism model was proposed in Scheme 2 . 4 Conclusion In this work, the structure-activity strategy comparison of two different precipitants on MnO x catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR was studied in detail. XRD confirmed that CO3 2- could transfer active manganese precursor from MnCO3 to the ultimate Mn2O3 phase with temperature. For comparison, the OH-bearing precipitant facilitated the phase transition of MnO x from Mn3O4 to the final Mn5O8 phase. Such results confirmed the anions did play a crucial role in the phase formation of pure MnO x during the synthesis process. Further surface morphology defined that Mn-AC possessed a peculiar spherical feature while Mn-AH catalyst presented an accumulation of abundant nano-particles. The activity results suggested that Mn-AC catalyst possessed higher catalytic activity compared with Mn-AH catalyst, with over 60% conversion achieved from 100 to 225 °C and the maximum NO conversion reached ca. 85% at 175 °C. Such results reflected that the peculiar spherical feature with Mn-AC was more conducive to the reactivity of catalysts than the nano-particles structure with Mn-AH catalyst. More abundant manganese ions with higher valence and surface oxygen favored the excellent redox properties of Mn-AC catalyst, which was supported by the H2-TPR analysis. In addition, Mn-AC catalyst possessed the stronger surface acidity in whichever strength or quantity than Mn-AH catalyst, which served as an important motivation for the difference in activity. In situ DRIFTS investigated the active intermediates reaction behaviors via the transient reaction. The results confirmed that both catalysts followed the E-R and L-H pathways while the L-H pathway was harder to occur than the former due to the intense NO x transformation over catalysts. On account of these analyses, the possible structure-activity strategy comparison model of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst was proposed. coredata.dc:description: Herein, the structure-activity strategy comparison of two different precipitants on MnO x catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR was investigated in detail. XRD results confirmed that ammonium carbonate (denoted as AC) could transfer manganese precursor from MnCO3 to Mn2O3 phase with temperature from 80 to 450 °C, while ammonium hydroxide (denoted as AH) facilitated the phase transition of MnO x from Mn3O4 to the final Mn5O8 phase. Further morphology defined that Mn-AC catalyst possessed a peculiar spherical feature while Mn-AH catalyst presented an accumulation of abundant nano-particles. The activity results suggested that Mn-AC catalyst possessed higher activity compared with Mn-AH catalyst at lower temperature, with over 60% conversion achieved from 100 to 225 °C and the maximum NO conversion reached circa (denoted as ca.) 85% at 175 °C. In addition, Mn-AC catalyst possessed stronger surface acidity and redox properties than Mn-AH catalyst, which served as an important motivation for the difference in activity. More manganese ions with higher valence and surface oxygen favored the superior redox circle of Mn-AC catalyst. Transient reaction revealed that the catalysts followed both Eley–Rideal (E-R) and Langmuir–Hinshelwood (L-H) pathways while the L-H pathway was harder to occur than the former due to the intense NO x transformation over catalysts. On account of these analyses, the possible structure-activity strategy comparison model of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Structure-activity strategy comparison of (NH4)2CO3 and NH4OH precipitants on MnO x catalyst for low-temperature NO abatement
